desc: SUZ12 encodes a component of the polycomb group of transcriptional repressors that acts through methylation of histone H3 lysine 27. SUZ12 mutation has been identified in hematologic disease and sarcomas.

The SUZ12 (Suppressor of Zeste 12) is a component of the Polycomb Repressive Complex 2 (PRC2), which is responsible for transcriptional repression by catalyzing di- and tri-methylation of Histone H3 lysine 27 (H3K27) (PMID: 16630818). SUZ12 is necessary for both the histone methyltransferase activity and silencing function of PRC2 (PMID: 15225548), which are important in regulating development and expression of cell identity genes, including the HOX cluster of genes (PMID: 16625203). SUZ12 is commonly mutated in malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors, T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, and myeloid neoplasms (PMID: 25240281, 22237151, 22237106, 23486531). Translocations involving SUZ12 have been identified in endometrial stromal tumors (PMID: 11371647). Mutations in SUZ12 can cooperate with Ras pathway signaling in cellular transformation and may sensitize tumor cells to bromodomain inhibitors (PMID: 25119042).
